A playerâ€™s turn flows through three mandatory phases and then ends.  

1. Roll for production  
   â€¢ Throw both dice.  
   â€¢ Each terrain hex whose number matches the roll produces. Every player with a settlement bordering that hex takes one matching resource card; a city collects two.  
   â€¢ If a 7 appears, no hex produces. Instead, every player with more than seven resource cards discards half (rounded down). The active player moves the robber to any hex, steals one random resource from a player with a bordering settlement or city, and the robbed hex is blocked from producing until the robber is moved again.  

2. Trade (optional, any number of times)  
   â€¢ Domestic trade: propose exchanges with other players; the active player decides which offers to accept.  
   â€¢ Maritime trade: swap cards with the bank at 4 : 1, 3 : 1 at a generic port you control, or 2 : 1 at a matching specialty port.  
   â€¢ You may intermix trade and building, repeating as often as you wish while you remain the active player.  

3. Build/Play development (optional, any order, any number)  
   â€¢ Spend resources to:  
     â€“ build a road (brick + lumber),  
     â€“ build a settlement (brick + lumber + wool + grain),  
     â€“ upgrade a settlement to a city (3 ore + 2 grain),  
     â€“ buy a development card (ore + wool + grain).  
   â€¢ You may play one previously purchased development card, resolving its effect; Victory Point cards are revealed only when they give you the win. Newly bought development cards cannot be played this turn.  
   â€¢ Roads and buildings must obey distance, placement, and supply limits; development cards may never be traded.  

4. End of turn  
   â€¢ Return any unspent resources to your hand, pass the dice clockwise; the player to your left begins their turn.

The Campaign for North Africa.content:
Ground (Close) Assault is the hand-to-hand phase of combat that occurs after artillery and anti-tank fire.  
It is always initiated by the phasing player and always fought between adjacent hexes.

1. When and who may attack  
   â€¢ Close Assault is the final step of the Combat Segment.  
   â€¢ Any phasing combat unit that possesses an Offensive Close Assault Rating may assault an adjacent enemy hex unless the terrain forbids it (e.g., no motorized assault into Salt Marsh; no assault up an escarpment without first dismounting, etc.).  
   â€¢ Each enemy-occupied hex can be assaulted only once per Combat Segment, but any number of friendly hexes may contribute to that single assault.

2. Pre-assault sequence  
   a. Position guns and armor (Front/Back).  
   b. Execute all Barrages.  
   c. Non-phasing units may Retreat-Before-Assault.  
   d. Both players secretly assign each participating TOE Strength Point to one of three states: Anti-Armor, Close Assault, or Withheld.  
   e. Resolve Anti-Armor fire and remove losses.  
   f. Proceed to Close Assault with the surviving TOE points that were assigned to Close Assault.

3. Forming the assault force  
   â€¢ You may commit any portion of a unitâ€™s TOE points, but if less than 50 % of a unitâ€™s available points are used the attack is automatically a Probe, not a full Close Assault.  
   â€¢ Tanks must be accompanied by an equal number of infantry-class TOE points from the same hex; for every 1-3 unsupported tank TOE points, one Actual Close Assault point is lost (maximum â€“4).  
   â€¢ If the phasing side now has at least twice the raw Close Assault strength of the defender, the column shifts two in its favour; additional shifts apply for formal organizational size differences (company vs. battalion, battalion vs. regiment, etc.).

4. Calculating the Assault Differential  
   â€¢ Total each sideâ€™s Actual Close Assault Points (after Anti-Armor losses, Combined-Arms reductions, etc.).  
   â€¢ Subtract defender from attacker to get the Basic Assault Differential.  
   â€¢ Apply column shifts for:  
     â€“ Terrain in defenderâ€™s hex and terrain of each assault hexside (hexside effects are added to hex effects; only one hexside type may benefit the defender unless the same hexside contains two different terrain features).  
     â€“ Up-/down-slope or escarpment attacks (+1 attacker down-slope, â€“3 defender when attacker climbs an escarpment, etc.).  
     â€“ Morale: compare each sideâ€™s Adjusted Morale Rating and shift columns accordingly.  
     â€“ Size differential and special cases (all defending guns with no assault rating, all defenders pinned, etc.).

5. Resolving the assault  
   â€¢ Consult the Close Assault Combat Results Table using the final Differential column.  
   â€¢ Both players roll two dice (read sequentially, e.g., â€œ63â€).  
   â€¢ Cross-index the roll with the column on their own half of the table (attacker or defender) to obtain:  
     â€“ Percentage losses (converted to Raw Strength Point losses, then distributed proportionally among units in all involved hexes).  
     â€“ Captured result (a fraction of the defenderâ€™s losses become prisoners/equipment if the attacker survives).  
     â€“ Retreat distance (mandatory minimum; each hex not retreated costs the side an extra 10 % loss).  
     â€“ Engaged result (units are locked in combat until the end of the Operations Stage; leaving costs additional Capability Points).

6. After-effects  
   â€¢ Apply Vulnerability losses to forward guns and to all guns if an overrun occurred.  
   â€¢ Place Engaged markers where required; remove them at the end of the Operations Stage.  
   â€¢ The phasing player may now release reserves and resume movement/combat cycles if desired.

Key limitations  
â€¢ Motorized units may never assault up an escarpment; tanks may never attack alone without suffering Combined-Arms penalties.  
â€¢ A hex that was assaulted (or probed) cannot be assaulted again in the same Combat Segment.  
â€¢ Ammunition is automatically expended by both sides during Close Assault.

Ground Assault therefore combines fire preparation, secret force assignment, simultaneous anti-armor duels, and finally a differential-based, column-shifted close-quarters combat resolution that yields casualties, captures, retreats, or continuing melee (Engaged).

Yes. Tanks are governed by a whole family of rules that cover their movement capabilities, combat strengths, vulnerability to fire, logistical demands, mechanical reliability, and even what happens after they are knocked out.

1. Tank characteristics  
   â€¢ Every tank TOE Strength Point has a printed Capability-Point Allowance (20-25), Anti-Armor rating, Offensive and Defensive Close-Assault ratings, Armor-Protection rating, Vulnerability rating, Fuel-Rate, and Breakdown Adjustment Rating. These values are listed on the national Tank & Gun Characteristics Charts and are used whenever the tank moves, fights, refuels, or checks for mechanical failure.

2. Tank combat procedures  
   a. Anti-Armor Fire (14.0)  
      â€“ Tanks may fire their Anti-Armor rating or be targeted by enemy Anti-Armor fire.  
      â€“ Incoming Damage Points are absorbed against the tankâ€™s Armor-Protection rating; once absorbed points equal or exceed that rating, one TOE tank point is destroyed.  
   b. Close Assault (15.0)  
      â€“ Tanks may contribute their Close-Assault ratings, but for each tank TOE point there must be an equal infantry-class TOE point from the same hex; otherwise the tank force suffers â€“1 Actual Close-Assault point per 1-3 unsupported tanks (maximum â€“4).  
      â€“ Size-of-force and morale shifts apply as normal.  
   c. Combined sequence  
      1. Assign TOE points (Anti-Armor / Close-Assault / Withheld).  
      2. Resolve simultaneous Anti-Armor fire and remove tank losses.  
      3. Apply surviving Close-Assault points, with combined-arms adjustments, to determine the Assault Differential.

3. Special tank situations  
   â€¢ Capturing Destroyed Tanks (14.5): once a tank point is eliminated, a Destroyed-Tank marker is left; if the enemy later enters that hex, he may tow the wreck three hexes and attempt repair in a facility.  
   â€¢ Halftracks: certain Axis motorised infantry units count as â€œhalf-tracksâ€; if they are the only armored TOE in a hex, their Armor-Protection rating is doubled, but no more than two such points may be lost per Anti-Armor segment.  
   â€¢ Dummy Tank Formations (16.4): each side may construct up to three battalion-sized dummy tank units that look like real tanks to enemy reconnaissance but vanish if subjected to Close Assault or Anti-Armor fire.  
   â€¢ HQ tanks (3.35): some armoured division/brigade headquarters counters contain one TOE â€œplatoonâ€ of tanks that may fight only if no other combat units are attached.

4. Reliability and repair  
   â€¢ Breakdown (21.0): tanks are vehicles and may suffer mechanical failure whenever they expend CP for movement; the Breakdown Adjustment on the tank chart shifts the die roll.  
   â€¢ Repair (22.0): broken-down tanks can be fixed in the field or at a repair facility; destroyed tanks that have been captured may be rebuilt under 22.4.  
   â€¢ Tank Recovery Squadrons may tow immobilised tanks to repair sites.

5. Logistics  
   â€¢ Tanks consume Fuel at their printed Fuel-Rate whenever they move.  
   â€¢ Ammunition is automatically expended whenever they fire Anti-Armor or participate in Close Assault.

In short, tanks in CNA are fully integrated into the system: they have distinct ratings, must cooperate with infantry for maximum effect, can be broken, repaired, captured, or even faked, and they form the centrepiece of both the Anti-Armor and Close-Assault subsystems.

are there rules for foot soldiers?

Yes.  â€œFoot soldiersâ€ are the gameâ€™s Infantry-type units and they are covered by a full set of rules that define how they move, fight, absorb losses, and can be upgraded or motorised.

1. What an Infantry-type unit is  
   â€¢ Any counter whose ID code is listed on the Unit-Characteristics Chart as â€œInfantry Bn-Eqâ€ or â€œInfantry Coy-Eqâ€ is a foot unit.  
   â€¢ One TOE Strength Point represents roughly 100-200 men.  
   â€¢ Infantry have no Vulnerability Rating, so they cannot be harmed by Anti-Armor fire, and they possess no Armor-Protection Rating.

2. Capability-Point Allowance (movement)  
   â€¢ Basic CPA is 8â€“10.  
   â€¢ A non-motorised unit may never voluntarily expend more than 150 % of that base during its portion of an Operations Stage (an 8 may spend up to 12 CP; a 10 up to 15).  
   â€¢ If trucks are attached, the battalion becomes â€œmotorisedâ€ and immediately uses the CPA of the truck (normally 20). If the trucks run out of fuel the men must dismount to assault (49.4).

3. Terrain and assault limits  
   â€¢ A motorised infantry unit may never assault up an escarpment and may not assault into Salt-Marsh hexes while still on its trucks; it must first dismount.  
   â€¢ Leg infantry pay the normal CP costs shown on the Terrain Effects Chart to cross slopes, ridges, wadis, etc.

4. Combat functions  
   a. Barrage class â€“ Infantry-class (all infantry, engineers, HQs).  
   b. Close Assault â€“ Every infantry point has an Offensive and Defensive Close-Assault rating (typically â€œ2/3â€).  
   c. Combined Arms â€“ For every TOE Strength Point of tanks taking part in a Close Assault, there must be an equal TOE Strength Point of infantry, machine-gun, or heavy-weapons from the SAME hex, otherwise the tanks lose one Actual Assault point per one-to-three unsupported tanks (max â€“4).  
   d. Size Differential â€“ If the attacker has twice the raw infantry strength of the defender, the column shifts two in the attackerâ€™s favour. Additional shifts apply for company vs. battalion, regiment vs. brigade, etc.

5. Training, morale, and upgrades  
   â€¢ Each battalion has a Basic Morale rating (-3 to +3). Certain Commonwealth units begin below that value and must be trained up.  
   â€¢ Infantry battalions with specific ID codes may later be â€œaugmentedâ€ by anti-tank TOE points or receive an outright upgrade (rules 19.9, 20.77).

6. Logistical factors  
   â€¢ Infantry consume ammunition whenever they fire (50.0).  
   â€¢ They do not consume fuel unless being carried in trucks.  
   â€¢ They never make Breakdown checks unless mounted on vehicles.

7. Stacking and attachment  
   â€¢ An infantry battalion counts the standard number of Stacking Points shown on the Stacking Chart and may be attached, detached, or entered on a parent HQâ€™s log sheet like any other combat unit.

In short, foot soldiers follow all general land-movement and combat rules, plus specific provisions for their lower CPA, inability to be damaged by anti-tank fire, the need to escort tanks in Close Assault, and their optional conversion to motorised status by attaching truck points.
